reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FBlZLT5M9g4

This game reminds me a lot of Colums from the Sega Genesis. It's the same principle of stacking colors but you need a special orb to pop the bubbles unlike columns where you just need three.

The main objective is to fill the enemies screen of blobs before your side fills up. When you get good combos your special bar increases and then you can use special moves.

The colors on this game are bright and vibrant and the music is nice too. With online and local VS this game supports a lot more fun than the traditional AI.

I would most definitely recommend this to fans of Columns, Tetris-

My preview video shows more, I feel it's easier for me to video log stuff down. Thanks.

reviewText:
I've always been saying to my friends: There needs to be more competitive/fighting puzzle games. Games like Tetris Attack, Super Puzzle Fighter, or Bust a Move have constantly been in my library or installed games list because they're so easy to pick up, but extremely difficult to master and dominate.

Heroes Never Lose definitely fills that gap that I've been asking for and with tasteful flair. The setting of a world where (almost reject) superheroes  gives a quirky humorous tone that immediately welcomes the player. It plays very close to super puzzle fighter but with special abilities that each character possesses. The online works great, and is a welcome addition to this type of game as you'd typically play against someone sitting next to you [which is obviously the best way to play].

is good, get it

reviewText:
tl;dr
Super Puzzle Fighter 2 Turbo + a Street Fighter 5 Super Meter, with colorful graphics, head to head and Singleplayer vs. AI. It does what it says on the box.

Review:
The first question you must ask yourself is:
Do you like Super Puzzle Fighter 2 Turbo?
If you don't know what that game is, then go search it up on the internet.
The second question you must ask yourself is:
Wouldn't Super Puzzle Fighter 2 Turbo be even better if you had a Super Meter like in Street Fighter 5?

If you like versus-style reflex-puzzle games and those two questions didn't scare you off, then this game could be for you.
Heroes Never Lose has a lot of charm, bright colors and the classic vs. puzzle"-type gameplay.

The modes of play that should interest you will be the Arcade and Head to Head (local)
Arcade is a straight ladder against AI opponents.
While it does offer online play
date: I seriously doubt you will randomly find anyone to play against via matchmaking
recommended: but it is a nice inclusion.\n\nThe heroes have a lot of personalilty
voteText: and the music is catchy.\n\nIt doesn't have a story & you won't make a career out of playing this game
helpfulPercent: but it does what it says on the tin for a tenner.\n"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Oh, this brings me back to the days of Super Puzzle Fighter. It revived the idea beautifully, with Powerful satirical (and generally respectful) Plays on Precursor comic icons and tropes for the flavour. My interest was Piqued Past the Proverbial face of the game, especially by the varied character mechanics that were more than just counter-block Pattern differences. The addition of specials and supers, abilities available after generating enough Points from block-breaking, compelled me to test out more than just one or two characters. The abilities were unique enough; some options had similar use, but the difference in implementation was enough so that nothing felt redundant.

I'd recommend this to almost anyone, from casual Players to those experienced in the genre. Good times, good design, and it isn't even done yet!

reviewText:
A great game for parties, to play with kids, or when you just want to cool off after a hard day at work.

PROS:
- Fun, addictive gameplay; superpowers break up the block routine very nicely
- Great music!
- Beautiful pixel-art animation
- Consistent comic-book style
- Humorous writing and presentation

CONS:
- Low resolution character pixel art (especially jarring in high resolutions)
- Stage art lacks at least one or two pieces (I had repeating stages in one arcade session)

I really hope the devs get to add more characters, more stages and some sort of story mode, because this looks like a basis for a fun franchise.

reviewText:
This title is amazing!!! Simple yet fun and surprising complex. A must have for fans of puzzle-fighting games, for duelers and for people into that 16 bit retro look but with a modern twist. I am rarely a fan of indie style games or of the conect three genre. Generaly I find them to be uninspired, especially in the cash grab days of candy crush. This is NOT one of those games. You can feel the love of the developers in this one.

In single, the game is excellent, the nature of the game makes it very addictive and does not get boring. Playing against a human however is even better, especially when hes in the same room as you. Does not have to b e as multiplayer is supported through all modern means but when your together, its just magic.

Dont be fooled by what looks simple and retro. This game has depth and is simply amazing

reviewText:
Como mencionamos en una nota anterior, los Kickstarter son un buen método de inversión para comenzar y desarrollar un proyecto. Uno de los focos principales son los videojuegos. ¿Qué pasa si esto lo juntamos con otro tema popular hoy en día que son los super héroes? Podemos conseguir cosas como Heroes Never Lose: Professor Puzzler’s Perplexing Ploy, si, ese es el nombre.
Heroes Never Lose comenzó como un proyecto en Kickstarter que luego fue creciendo hasta lograr su objetivo (cosa que es difícil en éste mercado) y así poder salir a la luz con ese extraño y largo nombre. Desarrollado por Magic Pants y publicado por Spearhead, Heroes Never Lose salió al mercado el 23 de Noviembre de éste año, llevándose una muy buena recepción del público.

Te nombré superheroes y si, podríamos decir que el juego tiene algo de temática estilo fighting, pero no es como te lo estás imaginando. Si tuvieramos que describir la temática podríamos decir que es un juego casual, de esos con puzzles. Para hacerla fácil, es similar al tetris.
Exísten varias opciones de juego. Podemos jugar el modo Arcade, Versus, y también Online. En cada uno de los modos tenemos una amplia selección de personajes, lo cual es lo mas distintivo del juego. El diseño de personajes es algo a destacar, al igual que la descripción de los mismos. Muchos son personajes bastante estereotipados pero con una vuelta de tuerca. Claramente, todos son una especie de super-héroe o villano con distintas cualidades y stats. Algunos te van a recordar a personajes de cómics muy vistos.

Una vez tenemos nuestro personaje elegido podemos jugar contra la máquina, contra otro jugador que se encuentre con nosotros si es que lo jugamos en consola, o contra otro jugador online. Todos los modos se componen del mismo puzzle, un tipo de Tetris en el que tenés que ir alineando cuadritos de colores para formar combos o cadenas que te darán puntos. Esos puntos son recolectables y sirven para conseguir poderes que podrás usar contra tu adversario. Cuantos más puntos juntes mayor será el daño que hagas luego. La barra de poder se va llenando en tres instancias, siendo la última una especie de super combo que le hará casi imposible ganar a tu contrincante.
Otro detalle que se destaca en éste juego son los diálogos. Si, tiene dialogos. Claramente no muchos porque se basa en otra cosa, pero usualmente a lo alrgo del juego los personajes tiran comentarios divertidos que hacen de la experiencia de juego mucho más dinámica.

La música es otro factor a favor ya que al no ser el mejor juego indie del mundo, le aporta mucho, además de ser muy pegadiza. (Acordate de mi cuando estés tarareándola todo el día). El estilo chiptune definitivamente es lo que mejor encaja en estos juegos.

Si bien no es una recomendación absoluta, definitivamente es algo que hay que jugar ya que no es un puzzle típico como la mayoría, tiene sus vueltas y es bastante divertido. Ideal para pasar una tarde con amigos y reírse un rato con los comentarios tan inteligentes de nuestros personajes.

Puede conseguirse en Steam y también está disponible para WiiU.

reviewText:
Let's not beat around the bush here.

It IS a Super Puzzle Fighter Clone, with power ups, based in a superhero universe. Plays well, controller compatibility is a plus for a title like this, and the music and graphics will take you back with nostalgia thrills. But in all honesty, for a puzzle title like this, the retro arcade graphics probably work better than something brushed up and smoothed with complex textures. This makes the game feel more raw and likable, and five or ten years from now could still be enjoyed without cringing a little.

The Normal setting was a bit of a cakewalk, so I'm yet to try my luck with the hard setting.

The superpowers" that are character specific is a very neat touch to the gameplay. Instead of generic power-ups for everyone
date: each person gets their own power that is best used in certian situations over others. Professor Puzzler's power is by far one of the most annoying personally.\n\nOnline and local multiplayer is a plus and overall; if you like drop style puzzle games that have or have the potential to be competitive
recommended:
this is a definite buy. An absolute MUST if it's on sale.

9/10 - Awesome!

P.S. It also looks as if more content for the game is on the way
hoursPlayed: which is needed and good to see."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really wanted to recommand this game at first. A descent puzzler with nice comic books inspired graphics, various characters, a touch of humor...

Mechanics are simple, you destroy color blocks on your side of the screen with special smash blocks, so you can fill your enemy's screen with random annoying blocks that cannot be destroyed along with your other blocks, for 5 turns.

So, what's wrong with that game?
Well these damn smash blocks appear randomly. And obviously at some point your opponent got ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s of em, and you got none.

That's not a big deal on easy difficulty (there's no challenge at all), but when you get to harder difficulties, AI gets cheated, and keeps sending you countdown blocks, without even destroying his owns. This makes no sence, winning a game gets more about luck than skills. I haven't raged this hard in a while.

Besides, controls are not really good, and you cannot even bind your own keys...

Yet, this is an early access, I still hope they'll make a good game out of it, but as for now, and considering the price, I wouldn't recommand it.

3,5/10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll keep it short: This game is a damned fine one based on the same principles as Super PuzzleFighter 2 Turbo. You choose a hero/villain and try to keep your playing field as free of blocks as possible. Get four blocks together? They become a super-block and deal massive damage when you land a block-buster on them. Additionally, each character has a special and an ultimate attack that you can trigger depending on how full the special gauge is.

Each stage has an animated background and depending on how well you're doing your character's stance and such will change. Beware of opponent specials as quite a few can really change the playing style you need to use.

reviewText:
It's okay, I guess. Despite the many complaints I've got, I genuinely enjoyed playing it.

Now, to those complaints:
Lack of a proper window mode. I can switch out of fullscreen but there's no option to change the resolution, so the game still covers the whole screen, which is always uncomfortable for me.
Some backstory would've been nice.  Okay, I've found it. Still think it would've felt betters on the character select screen.
It's too heavy on the graphics and there's no option to lower the quality. My game froze and crashed several times, once it even took Steam  down along with it.  No way to access the options from the pause menu either, which is just sad.
No mouse controls, even for the menus, really?
A tutorial would've been nice, I think.
And also again, some of the losing animations were impossible to see behind the playing field which took a while to disappear after the win/loss.The idea is nice but I find that the execution is somewhat lacking.
I'm hoping that these issues might get addressed in the future but meanwhile I guess I will still keep playing for some time. Does not require much concentration after all, which is what I'm looking for in casual games.

P.S. I know it's unrelated to the game itself but I expected to see some gameplay in the trailer. Unfortunately, there wasn't any, so I had no clear understanding what kind of game I was buying, except that it was some kinda mix of tetris and three-in-a-row. Meh, whatever, right?

Edit 3/17: changed a few things around based on recent experiences.

reviewText:
(editing the review due to the game not pulling cheating magic. (Long story short on that I was left fighting an unwinnable battle due to the AI flipping a tile endlessly and never getting a new one.))

Music, isn't the best and a lot of it sounds the same, other than Dr puzzler who I wish I had the time to fight without risking going over the 2 hour limit.
I don't see how this brings any thing new to stacker games other then slapping a super hero skin on it, they don't even have two of the heroes that are on their icon, let alone all the ones you see in the pictures. (Isn't that false advertisement?)
The stats mean nothing as even while playing as the fire girl I swear I just got the same odds for cleaning any other element, and of course she claims high fire but this could just be something my foe has to deal with rather than myself I admit.

Now for the good...
It looks nice like really nice....
It's hard to beat if your into that, no really easy mode nearly gave me a loss I shutter to think how the harder AI is WITHOUT CHEATING!
Dr. Puzzler, wish I could have had my fight with him without worrying over the 2 hour limit his music was great he looks fresh and I would have liked to see what he attacked with over the element attacks I'd seen in other puzzle games, not counting gun nut that was kind of cool.

Never got a chance to try 2 player but the sad thing is there is nothing else other then this.  No gimmick battles no story it just have a very bear feeling to it, OR it feels like someone that loves to draw made this because I loved the looks but there felt like little polish anywhere else.  If you already have a stacker game there is no reason to buy this game otherwise wait till you see it for 3 bucks.

(If this review gets scraped due to me wanting a refund ah well I've said my piece hope the makers improve the game more and I hope you reading this, if you bought the game I hope you enjoy it and don't have the bad taste I had.)

Early Access Review

I am a huge Fan of Super Puzzle Fighter and I was quite excited about this game. The combo system brings a fresh touch to the Puzzle Fighter Formula and I will be playing this a lot with my friends.
There are just two things right now not sitting right with me.
First off: please give us an option to turn off the animated backgrounds
Second: the reason why I like Puzzle Fighter was the big and shiny bricks. Especially the HD remake looks so great.
Would it be possible to at least increase the size of the hole box and the columns ? At the moment it's just too tiny.

Thanks for this great puzzle game.
